Cool. Wind River's adoption of Linux happened more recently than that. Quoting a bit more from Wikipedia: "Wind River Linux "Wind River's Linux product is source code and a build system that generate runtime images suitable for embedded devices. It supports a variety of architectures, including ARM, MIPS, PowerPC, IA32 and SPARC. "In 2004, Wind River announced a partnership with Red Hat to create a new Linux-based distribution for embedded devices.[10] Wind River has since ended its partnership with Red Hat and now ships its own Linux distribution optimized for embedded Linux development. "Wind River released the first version of its embedded Linux distribution, Platform for Network Equipment - Linux Edition (PNE-LE) 1.0 in 2005.[11] It was registered against the Carrier Grade Linux 2.0 specification and supported IA32 and PPC architectures. They added other platforms in subsequent releases, General Purpose Platform - Linux Edition (GPP-LE) and Platform for Consumer Devices - Linux Edition PCD-LE) starting in version 1.4. "On March 16, 2009, Wind River announced Wind River Linux 3.0.[12] "On February 20, 2007, FSMLabs' embedded market was acquired by Wind River Systems. Wind River maintains the free versions of RTLinux previously offered by FSMLabs;[13] and Wind River committed to continue to offer the FSMLab approach to RTLinux as part of their product line rebranded as Wind River Real-Time Core for Wind River Linux. "On August 7, 2007, Palm Inc. announced that it had chosen Wind River Systems as the software solution for its (later aborted) Palm Foleo. "In 2008, Wind River announced cooperation with BMW, Intel and Magneti Marelli for development of a Linux-based open-source platform to control in-car electronics,[14] which was extended in the GENIVI Alliance in 2009.[15]" ______________________________________ So Wind River definitely is involved with Linux. What's not clear to me is what kernel underlies current versions of VwWorks, and in particular the one that controls Curiosity on Mars. Wind River ads make much of providing "deterministic realtime" systems, meaning that responses are guaranteed to occur within a certain time interval, and Linux as normally designed doesn't necessarily make such a guarantee, even if it does beat the time limit on average. Wind River is certainly capable of modifying the Linux kernel to provide "deterministic realtime" performance, but whether it has or not is not clear from information I've seen so far.

Topic.Title: FASTER GAMING WITH LINUX THAN WINDOZE !!

Message.Msg: SKANK, explain to that moron brother of yours before he has a nervous breakdown, "INSPECTOR - WRONG" that >>>>>>>>>>>>> Still, microsoft seemed pleased with the results despite not making the top 500.<<<<< means there are NO windows server HPC world class supercomputers in the Top500.

Actually, it looks like it works the other way: Wind River Linux runs as a low-priority process inside a proprietary realtime micro-kernel. The proprietary (non-Linux) component is resposible for the realtime support. Here's a whitepaper on the Wind River website that discusses the implementation details of VxWorks and Wind River Linux. http://www.windriver.com/whitepapers/guestwp/servefile.php?f=rt_linux_vxworks_comparison_whitepaper.pdf They describe VxWorks as requiring a much smaller footprint than the realtime micro-kernel that run Wind River Linux. VxWorks appears to be the original small, deterministic, and proprietary component it's always been.

Topic.Title: FASTER GAMING WITH LINUX THAN WINDOZE !!

Message.Msg: Very true. Such speculations are just that, speculations. Certain aspects of my own experience incline me toward the view that he and wally are bots. First, I have a lot of experience with software of other kinds, so I have some sense of the typical ways software fails, as opposed to the typical foibles of real people. For one example among many I could give, I would expect a human idiot to have a lot more trouble operating a computer than he seems to have; with software, on the other hand, one is not particularly surprised at odd mixtures of competence and incompetence. Second, over time there have been several entities posting here that very clearly were bots, without any possible doubt. For some of them, it was evident not so much in what they had to say, but in the typography. For example, for one of them, every "content" word, i.e. any word other than common conjunctions, prepositions, articles etc, was enclosed in quotation marks, and if I remember correctly capitalized. For others, the typography was fine, but the content was so severely deficient both semantically and syntactically that such a person, if it was a person, would be utterly unable to operate a computer. One, long ago, struck me as a probable schizophrenic at the time, because of the word-salad character of its utterances, but in retrospect was almost certainly a bot. I look at it as an informal Turing Test. Entities posting here might only be trying to convince others that they are people, but might actually be software. How can one decide? It's an entertaining game, to compensate for the boredom of dealing with the cyphers all the time...

As it turns out, although the original version of VxWorks was based on the VRTX core, Wind River later replaced all the VRTX code with stuff they wrote themselves. The split between VRTX and VxWorks happened sometime back in the late 1980s.

At this point in the discussion, aren't you the one who's on the hook to provide some kind of conclusive evidence? Can you offer anything to support your claim that the current implementation of VxWorks is Linux-derived? There's a lot of data arguing against your position: The VxWorks driver model isn't in the least bit Linux-like, the licensing model certainly doesn't look like open source, VxWorks kernel fits nicely in 64kb, etc. Also, were you confusing VxWorks with QNX? The QNX folks open-sourced parts of their RTOS about five years ago. Is that what you were remembering?

Topic.Title: M$ is pushing users and vendors to Macs and Linux

Message.Msg: yawn..... MS is not even in the same ballpark of demanding control when compared with Apple. They have certainly had issues, but they develop and deliver a functional and capable API, development toolset, and still continue to dominate the desktop market in the enterprise. Linux is great, but hasn't got anywhere near the numbers of capable individuals who can provide support, development, and network integration. Microsoft seems to be stepping up and setting the standard with premium hardware which will allow the OS to perform as designed. Many hardware manufacturers and OEMs have cut corners to sell cheaper products, which MS has taken hits for over the years. With a premium example hardware line, these faults will now more likely be directed where they belong. MS can then focus more on the actual software issues.
